user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32                             status;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(impl->dl_handle, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
extern OS_impl_module_internal_record_t OS_impl_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    /* cppcheck-suppress unusedStructMember */
    void *dl_handle;
} OS_impl_module_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(void *dl_handle, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    const char *dlError; /*  Pointer to error string   */
    void *      Function;
    int32       status;

    status = OS_ERROR;

    /*
     * call dlerror() to clear any prior error that might have occurred.
     */
    dlerror();
    Function = dlsym(dl_handle, SymbolName);
    dlError  = dlerror();

    /*
     * For the POSIX DL implementation, if the symbol does not exist
     * then dlerror() is supposed to return non-null.  This is intended
     * to differentiate between valid symbols which are actually 0/NULL
     * and invalid symbols that do not exist.
     *
     * Some implementations do _not_ implement this detail, and dlerror()
     * still returns NULL after looking up an invalid symbol name.
     *
     * In practice, this is expected to be used for looking up functions
     * and as such all valid symbols should be non-NULL, so NULL is considered
     * an error even if the C library doesn't consider this an error.
     */
    if (dlError != NULL)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: %s\n", SymbolName, dlError);
    }
    else if (Function == NULL)
    {
        /* technically not an error per POSIX, but in practice should not happen */
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: dlsym() returned NULL\n", SymbolName);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)Function;

    return status;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No invariant controlling expressions were found in the provided code. Details:

- OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl: contains no control statements (no if/for/while/switch/do); it only computes an index with the macro and calls OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl, so there is no controlling expression to be invariant.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET / OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: the macro expands to an array indexing using OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok)). This is not a controlling expression; it is an index computation based on token->obj_idx which is not a compile-time invariant.

- OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl: the conditionals are if (dlError != NULL) and else if (Function == NULL). Both depend on runtime results of dlerror() and dlsym(), so they are not invariant. There are no loops with constant conditions or do-while constructs here that evaluate to a constant boolean.

- No other control constructs (for, while, do-while, switch) with constant or invariant expressions are present in the supplied code fragments. Therefore there are no code fragments needing investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
